annotation.TEXT: Intentional death here. Sandstorm Man isn't that difficult, but he's much bigger than most of the other Robot Masters in this game, making it easier to bump into him while using the Top Spin (the wind currents he creates also don't help matters).

Circuitry Man's stage is easily the hardest level in the demo. It's filled to the brim with yoku blocks, bottomless pits, and several high-damaging hazards (usually in the form of electric projectiles that fire out at set points). While you can use Beat's Super Adapter to bypass a good portion of the areas in this stage, there are a few that you actually have to do the intended way (at least, for the most part).

So then, as it turns out, there's some rather interesting explanations for a few things seen in this game so far - one of them being the music quality. I would advise pausing the video here and reading the description (especially since I don't want to flood the video with more annotations than necessary, like the first segment turned out). Either way, I feel the need to warn you to turn down your volume for this next stage (unless you didn't pause this like I suggested, in which case, sorry everyone - especially the headphone users).

I...don't even think I need to comment on the music anymore. What I will talk about however, is the Ride Armor. It essentially serves as a way to destroy certain blocks and deal more damage (its attacks have the same effect as Thunder Beam and Top Spin, but to an even higher degree). Despite dealing the most damage of anything in-game, it does have its fair share of issues, mainly in its extremely floaty controls. You gain momentum somewhat slowly at first while moving in it, and the actual hover controls on it are iffy at best (I'm still not sure how to get them to work properly).

This stage, fittingly enough, belongs to Otaku Man. To be honest, this is easily my favorite level in the game, if only for the concept alone. Despite being one the emptiest stages in the demo so far (even more-so than Shaman Man's), I still can't bring myself to hate on it that much; The weird visuals, the random posters, and the compressed music all make this a great concept for a parody stage. Hell, even Otaku Man's boss fight isn't that bad.
Another fair warning: I'd recommend keeping your volume down again for the next stage. This isn't only due to compression, but the music choice itself is...well, let's just say it doesn't help much.

Next to Circuitry Man's stage, Mirror Man's level is one of the more difficult levels in the current demo. Aside from having an abundance of similar hazards (yoku blocks, spikes, bottomless pits), this stage also has waterfalls that hinder your jumps and drag you down. Some of these are placed in rather evil locations, while one in particular is used for a downright awful trap (I'll point this out when it shows up).
<-- Spikes concealed by the waterfall. Not gonna lie, this is a dick move.

Fun fact: YouTube's content ID check managed to pick up on Arsenal Man and Circuitry Man's stage themes, but not this one. Why it doesn't recognize what's probably the most obvious song choice in this game is a bit beyond me.
The pistons/crushers are in the same boat as the moving platforms when it comes to coding errors (which I think Maelstormm may have addressed). The reason for this should become obvious very soon...

Celsius Man actually has a rather interesting gimmick during his boss fight. Though not seen here, he can change both sides of the screen to be coated in either heat or ice. In the final version, his projectiles will apparently take on Ikaruga-styled traits (where if you won't take damage if you come into contact with a projectile of the same color/element as the side of the screen you're standing on).

The lasers in this stage are yet another flavor of overly dangerous hazard. Five hits from them, and you're dead. It doesn't help that they also like to spawn suddenly while moving to the next screen (whether or not this is due to predetermined placement or if they're just on a set path/timer that transfers over to other screens, there's a good chance you'll be hit by at least one of them).
